ASIA-PAC

Dr Mahathir Mohamad was officially sworn in as Malaysia’s new PM after his Pakatan Harapan coalition took a majority of parliamentary seats in a shock election win. (Newswires)

Philippines central bank raised the overnight borrowing rate by 25bps to 3.25%; as expected. (Newswires)


UK

BoE kept rates at 0.5% as expected through 7-2 vote with Saunders and McCafferty the dissenters, while the BoE also voted 9-0 in favour of maintaining the current stock of UK government bond purchases and current stock of corporate bonds. (Newswires)
BoE made no mention of the historical guidance that rates will need to rise at a somewhat faster pace and greater extent than markets are currently pricing in, although it reiterated any future rate hikes are likely to be at a gradual pace and to a limited extent.
QIR Forecasts:
GDP Growth: 2018 Q2:1.4% (Prev.1.8 %), 2019 Q2: 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%), 2020 Q2: 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%), 2021 Q2: 1.7%
CPI Inflation: 2018 Q2: 2.4% (Prev. 2.7%), 2019 Q2: 2.1% (Prev. 2.2%), 2020 Q2: 2.0% (Prev. 2.1%), 2021 Q2: 2.0%
BoE Governor Carney said the key question is whether the Q1 weakness is temporary but added that if the economy evolves as expected in the May monetary policy report, modest tightening will be needed.

BoE Governor Carney also later commented he expects an interest rate hike this year if there are no shocks to the economy and that it's most likely that rates will go up over the course of the next year, although they will adjust policy if the economy slows. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

US equity futures rose from the Wall Street open and boosted from the slightly softer US CPI report which hints the Fed may decide to hike rates at a slower pace, also from a technical perspective the Emini broke back above 2700 and the April high. All sectors finished in the green on Thursday trade, with Telecoms and Healthcare outperforming. Stock specifics, Booking Holdings (BKNG) beat on both top and bottom line, however they forecast their Q2 results to be lower than analyst estimates which saw the stock as low as 5.5% on Thursday. L Brands also an underperformer today as they lowered Q1 eps guidance, LB saw intraday lows of ~10%. On the flipside, SPX outperformers were Century Link (CTL), who gave a strong boost to the telecom sector, following a strong earnings report. Envision Healthcare (EVHC) were higher today following reports in the NY Post that KKR (KKR) are considering an USD 11bln bid for the company. Retailers were hit today with Macy’s (M) underperforming the retail complex following a downgrade from Morgan Stanley, who predict they will report earnings below street estimates for the fiscal year. SPX +0.94% at 2793, NDX +1.02% at 6964, DJI +0.80% at 24739.

Treasuries finished slightly higher for the day, following the miss on CPI which alleviated fear of inflation gearing up in the economy. Yields on the long-end of the curve were lower by c.3bps at settlement. The 5s30s spread was the lowest since 2007 and narrower by c.4bps following the solid 27bln 30yr bond auction, which stopped-through by 0.8bps. The stop-through was the largest for a new bond at auction since November 2015. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 4 ticks higher at 119-15+.

US MARKET WRAP 10 May 2018: BoE unchanged, US core CPI soft, oil gave up gains
content:
• * SNAP-SHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries higher, DXY soft, GBP softer, Crude slightly up
  • * REAR-VIEW: BoE rate decision, US CPI
  • * AHEAD: Canadian labour market, US Uni of Mich, Fed’s Bullard and ECB’s Draghi to speak

 

*BANK OF ENGLAND: The BoE voted 7-2 to keep rates unchanged at 0.5% as expected; dissent from Saunders and McCafferty.  Members saw value in watching how data unfolded in the coming months and wait to see whether softness in Q1 would persist. The key question raised by Governor Carney during the press conference, was whether the weakness seen in Q1 was temporary, after some of the drop-off was attributed to adverse weather conditions at the start of the year. Nonetheless, the MPC placed more weight on labour data and business surveys, reiterating that any future rate increases are likely to be at a gradual pace and to a limited extent. Later in the day, Governor Carney told the BBC he expects an interest rate hike this year.  

*NAFTA: Canada's Freeland is willing to work as long as necessary for a NAFTA agreement and she remains optimistic about reaching a deal, noting that parties ‘definitely getting close to the final objective’. Sources added that the US has set a deadline of May 17th or 18th for a deal to be done.

*DATA: US CPI figures rose from the previous month but posted smaller than expected gains. The softness in the core measures was attributed to new and used car prices, airline fares and health care commodities costs, whilst shelters prices placed mild pressure on the figures. Nevertheless, analysts at Oxford Economics noted that overall inflation continues to indicate a gradual build up of inflationary-pressure, as the economic momentum remains strong, supported by the fiscal stimulus effect and a tight labour market

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.94% at 2793, NDX +1.02% at 6964, DJI +0.80% at 24739.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: +0.35%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.73%, Energy: +0.81%, Financials: +0.71%, Health Care: +1.20%, Industrials: +0.74%, Materials: +0.79%, Technology: +1.13%, Telecoms: +1.80%, Utilities: +1.28%.

US equity futures rose from the Wall Street open and boosted from the slightly softer US CPI report which hints the Fed may decide to hike rates at a slower pace, also from a technical perspective the Emini broke back above 2700 and the April high.

All sectors finished in the green on Thursday trade, with Telecoms and Healthcare outperforming. Stock specifics, Booking Holdings (BKNG) beat on both top and bottom line, however they forecast their Q2 results to be lower than analyst estimates which saw the stock as low as 5.5% on Thursday. L Brands also an underperformer today as they lowered Q1 eps guidance, LB saw intraday lows of ~10%. On the flipside, SPX outperformers were Century Link (CTL), who gave a strong boost to the telecom sector, following a strong earnings report. EnvisionHealthcare (EVHC) were higher today following reports in the NY Post that KKR (KKR) are considering an USD 11bln bid for the company. Retailers were hit today with Macy’s (M) underperforming the retail complex following a downgrade from Morgan Stanley, who predict they will report earnings below street estimates for the fiscal year.

* CRUDE: WTI crude futures settle higher by USD 0.22 at USD 71.36/bbl, Brent crude futures settle higher by USD 0.26 at USD 77.57/bbl.

Oil prices came off their best levels seen this week as traders took profits in the wake of the US withdrawal from the Iran nuclear agreement. Prices also remained subdued after Iran's oil minister Zanganeh noted he does not see an impact on Tehran's oil and after OPEC stated it is too soon to tell whether extra oil is needed due to US sanctions, as it evaluates shortfalls in crude output. Note the he matter will be discussed at the monitoring committee meeting on May 22nd.

Iran oil minister says he prefers oil prices of USD 65/bbl.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 4 ticks higher at 119-15+.

Treasuries finished slightly higher for the day, following the miss on CPI which alleviated fear of inflation gearing up in the economy. Yields on the long-end of the curve were lower by c.3bps at settlement. The 5s30s spread was the lowest since 2007 and narrower by c.4bps following the solid 27bln 30yr bond auction, which stopped-through by 0.8bps. The stop-through was the largest for a new bond at auction since November 2015.

*FOREX: *DXY: The index has recoiled further from fresh 93.400+ YTD peaks to circa 92.500 in wake of more underwhelming US inflation data and rebounded slightly later in the session just above 93.600.

*GBP, NZD: The GBP fell after the Bank of England decision where they lowered inflation forecasts and kept interest rates unchanged. Carney’s suggestion that rates will still rise this year provided some support as the pair regained 1.3500. NZDUSD has pared losses amid broad based USD weakness and rebounded above 0.6950 from a near 0.6900 after some pressure seeing after the latest RBNZ meeting revealed a 2-way stance on the outlook for rates with new Governor Orr underlining that the prospect of an ease or hike are evenly balanced.

*AUD: The best G10 performer, partly on the back of the Kiwi’s plummet as AUDNZD jumped over 1.0800, but also on strength in commodity prices, with AUDUSD stronger against the Greenback and holding well-above 0.7500.

*EUR, CAD: EURUSD reclaimed the 1.1900 handle, but perhaps conscious of more on Friday (1.75bln) as the pair drifted back from recovery peaks just shy of 1.1950. The Loonie extended its gains against the USD to just over 1.2750, amid some relatively positive NAFTA updates.

*JPY, CHF: The safe-havens also prospered from the Dollar’s data-related downturn, with USDJPY now back below 109.50 from around 110.00 at one stage and USDCHF retesting parity from just over 1.0050 at the high.

*TRY: The Lira endured more choppy trade, with another bout of weakness and slump to 4.3000 vs the USD after day 1 of the emergency meeting to discuss the Try’s plight and state of the economy promising action, but not producing anything concrete. However, USDTRY pulled back to around 4.2200 in the hope that the 2nd day of talks between the Government and CBRT delivers.

content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 17bln 30-year bonds

The US Treasury increased the auction sizes at the quarterly refunding announcement and will auction USD 73bln in 3-year notes (USD 31bln, Tuesday), 10-year notes (USD 25bln, yesterday) and 30-year bonds (USD 17bln, today) this week. With a total of USD 39.1bln maturing on 15th May, the auctions will raise USD 33.9bln in the week. The bidding deadline for the auction is 1800BST (1300 eastern time) with results expected shortly after.

Last month’s 10-year note auction was as average as they come; the auction was covered 2.41x, slightly below the 6-auction average of 2.44x but the auction stopped through the WI at the bidding deadline by 0.1bps. Dealers were also left with a slightly better than average 24.4%. Of the last six auctions, four have stopped through and two have tailed, most notably the January auction which saw a 2.1bps tail.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Usd undermined by CPI, but Gbp and Nzd underperform on CB factors
content:
DXY

The index has recoiled further from fresh 93.400+ ytd peaks to circa 92.500 in wake of more underwhelming US inflation data as core CPI missed consensus in m/m and y/y terms. The Greenback is lower almost across the board as a result, with only dovish Central Bank impulses preventing 2 of its major rivals from benefiting.

GBP/NZD

The aforementioned exceptions to the rule, with the Pound buffeted by the BoE and a wait-and-see stance on further policy normalisation from the majority of the MPC, as only McCafferty and Saunders retained their votes for a hike. Cable is now testing bids around and just under 1.3500 again having squeezed up to 1.3600 just ahead of the start of ‘super’ Thursday at high noon, while Eur/Gbp has rebounded over 0.8800. Similarly, the Kiwi remains pressured after the latest RBNZ meeting revealed a 2-way stance on the outlook for rates with new Governor Orr underlining that the prospect of an ease or hike are evenly balanced. Nzd/Usd has pared some losses, but is struggling the rebound above 0.6950 from a near 0.6900 low.

AUD

The best G10 performer, partly on the back of the Kiwi’s plummet as Aud/Nzd jumped over 1.0800, but also on strength in commodity prices, with Aud/Usd overcoming resistance and big option expiry interest at 0.7500 before the NY cut.
 

EUR/CAD

Both ending the EU session around 0.5% ahead vs the Buck, with Eur/Usd reclaiming the 1.1900 handle, and again ahead of decent expiry interest at the big figure (2.5 bn) rolling off today, but perhaps conscious of more on Friday (1.75 bn) as the pair drifted back from recovery peaks just shy of 1.1950. The Loonie extended its gains against the Usd to just over 1.2750, but bounced towards 1.2800 as oil prices retreat from their best levels and Canadian new house prices came in flat, albeit bang in line with expectations.

JPY/CHF

The safe-havens also prospered from the Dollar’s data-related downturn, with Usd/Jpy now back below 109.50 from around 110.00 at one stage and Usd/Chf retesting parity from just over 1.0050 at the high.

TRY

The Lira endured more choppy trade, with another bout of weakness and slump to 4.3000 vs the Usd after day 1 of the emergency meeting to discuss the Try’s plight and state of the economy promising action, but not producing anything concrete. However, Usd/Try pulled back to around 4.2200 in the hope that the 2nd day of talks between the Government and CBRT delivers.

BoE May Meeting Summary: BoE votes 7-2 to keep rates unchanged at 0.5% as expected; dissent from Saunders and McCafferty
content:
Key judgements:

Vote split on the base rate: 7-2 in favour of keeping rates unchanged

Vote split on corporate bonds: 9-0 in favour of maintaining the current stock of corporate bonds

Vote split on APF: 9-0 in favour of maintaining the current stock of UK government bond purchases

Growth: Q1 GDP of 0.1% was 0.3pp lower than expected in February and 0.2pp than expected in March. However, MPC believe that the slowing in Q1 GDP growth has been overstated in the prelim release and believe that over time Q1 will be revised higher to 0.3% and thereafter look for 0.4% in Q2.

Inflation: 2.5% CPI in March was lower than expected in the Feb QIR. Inflation rates of the most import-intensive components of CPI appear to have peaked. Impact of GBP depreciation while remains significant, is likely to fade a little faster than previously thought. CPI target is expected to be met in two years.

Rates: No mention of the historical guidance of: rates will need to rise at a somewhat faster pace and greater extent than markets are currently pricing in. Reiterated that any future rate increases were likely to be at a gradual pace and to a limited extent.

Brexit: Minutes offer no new view by the MPC on the matter

Wages: Wage growth are firming gradually and broadly as expected.

Labour market: Hiring intentions remain strong and the unemployment rate has fallen slightly further over the past 3 months.

Slack: MPC continues to judge that the UK economy has a limited degree of slack

Case for unchanged: Members saw value in seeing how data unfolded in the coming months and to see whether softness in Q1 would persist.

Case for lifting rates: Saw Q1 GDP as erratic and due to temp factors. Placed more weight on labour data and business surveys. Reduction in pass-through of GBP on inflation would not materially impact the inflation profile in the medium term.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Energy prices come off overnight highs in which crude prices extended on the advances as traders adjust to supply disruption concerns
  • Dollar losing a bit more impetus below 93.000 while Gbp/Usd is now trying to extend its rebound beyond 1.3600
  • Looking ahead, highlights include BoE rate decision, minutes and QIR, US CPI and weekly jobs

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded positive across the board following the energy-fuelled upside on Wall St, where oil names outperformed as crude gained in the wake of Trump's withdrawal from the Iran nuclear agreement and DoEs. As such, ASX 200 (+0.2%) was led by the energy sector as oil edged fresh multi-year highs last seen in 2014 and with RBOB also at its best levels since mid-2015, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) was also marginally higher amid earnings and with Mitsubishi Motors shares outpacing the broader market after it beat on its FY net and guided sales higher. Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) and Hang Seng (+0.9%) shrugged off another liquidity drain by the PBoC to trade positive in which Hong Kong resumed its recent trend of outshining its regional peers, while participants also digested mixed Chinese inflation figures that showed CPI missed estimates at 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.9% although PPI growth gathered pace for the 1st time in 7-months to 3.4% as expected. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with demand lacking amid gains in riskier assets while a 10yr inflation-indexed auction was also largely ignored and failed to spur price action.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day and CNY 10bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 20bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3768 (Prev. 6.3733)

Chinese CPI (Apr) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)

Chinese PPI (Apr) Y/Y 3.4% vs. Exp. 3.4% (Prev. 3.1%)

BoJ Summary of Opinions for April 26th-27th meeting stated it is appropriate to pursue powerful monetary easing under current guidelines as inflation is still a distant from the 2% target. Furthermore, the release noted that the rate of CPI Y/Y growth is likely to continue on its uptrend and increase toward 2%, while it added that BoJ is buying ETFs and risky assets as part of efforts to reach inflation goal but must look at potential merits and demerits of this action. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

White House commented that the US is preparing to add additional sanctions on Iran as soon as next week. (Newswires)

Israel Defense Forces conducted operations on Iran targets in Syria overnight. (Newswires)

Deputy head of Iran's revolutionary guards Salami said Europe cannot confront the US in the nuclear accord, adds diplomacy cannot help Iran, the only way is confrontation. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

RBNZ Interest Rate Decision (May) 1.75% vs. Exp. 1.75% (Prev. 1.75%). (Newswires)

RBNZ said that it expects to maintain OCR at this expansionary level for a considerable time and that current level is best to maximize sustainable employment and stable inflation, while it also noted the next direction in rates is equally a hike or cut.

RBNZ said domestic economic growth is robust, while it cited subdued wages, low food & import price inflation for low inflation. RBNZ also maintained forecasts for where it sees OCR through to September 2019 in which it OCR estimates were kept at 1.8% for September 2018 and June 2019, while the estimate for September 2019 was maintained at 1.90%.

ECB's Lane (Dovish) said he doesn't think this monetary policy rates are going to change dramatically in the coming years. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

It was reported that Italy's 5 Star and League have made significant steps to form a government, and expect to finalize everything in a short time. (Newswires)

EU officials suggest that the EU is looking to find a way forward to maintain trade between the UK and EU post-Brexit despite having reservations about PM May’s current plans. (Newswires)

UK Industrial Output YY (Mar) 2.9% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 2.2% Rev. 2.1%) (Newswires)

UK Industrial Output MM (Mar) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%)

EQUITIES

European equites trading mostly lower (Eurostoxx 50 -0.4%) ahead of the BoE rate decision, with the energy and telecoms sectors underperforming (-1.1% and -1.3% respectively). This resulting from Randgold Resources and BT’s (-8.2% and -9.0% respectively) uninspiring earnings, as well as BT’s announcement of job cuts. Financials are lower by 0.3% while RBS’s (+4.3%) lower than expected pay-out on MBS sales during the financial crisis, and UniCredit’s (+0.9%) positive financial results. Italy’s FTSE MIB is underperforming on the recent Italian political developments.

In stock specific news Next (+6.2%) raised guidance on warm weather boosting sales, and Alstom (+0.9%) announced a USD 3bln agreement with GE to exit multiple energy joint ventures.

FX

DXY

Losing a bit more impetus below 93.000 and looking for some support from US CPI data amidst expectations for firmer headline and core prints, but softer leads via PPI in the run up.

NZD/AUD

A very dovish hold from the RBNZ last night has hit the Kiwi hard, as the Central Bank signalled an even more prolonged period of unchanged policy and 50-50 odds that the next move in the OCR could be up or down. Nzd/Usd subsequently dived from a recovery high not far from 0.7000 to within a few pips of 0.6900, while the Aud/Nzd cross catapulted to just over 1.0800 from circa 1.0700 and lower in recent sessions. Conversely and consequently, Aud/Usd has continued its rebound from near 0.7400 lows towards 0.7500, but could be capped by mega option expiry interest at the big figure spread over the next few days (5 bn in total from today to May 16).

CAD

The Loonie continues to outperform G10 counterparts and climb alongside oil prices that have extended to the upside on the US-Iran nuclear deal breakdown and with draws in US crude inventories adding to supply concerns. Usd/Cad is now bids/support around 1.2775 vs peaks earlier in the week just over 1.3000 and may derive further direction from Canadian new house price data later (although the US inflation data is likely to be more influential for the pair).

EUR/CHF/GBP/JPY

All holding tight lines vs the Greenback, as Eur/Usd meanders between 1.1845-90 and largely shrugs off the latest ECB monthly economic report that essentially echoes the less upbeat tone of last month’s policy meeting assessment. Note, hefty expiries at 1.1900 today and on Friday of 2.5 bn and 1.75 bn respectively. Usd/Chf is back in familiar territory and recent trading parameters of 1.0000-50 having edged over the top at one stage, while Cable is choppy after regaining 1.3500+ status ahead of the May version of BoE ‘super’ Thursday that is almost bound to prompt a major reaction given all the variables around the rate verdict from the vote split, minutes, QIR and presser by Governor Carney. Note, little reaction to UK data which on balance was worse than forecast, especially March’s trade balance, but Gbp/Usd is now trying to extend its rebound beyond 1.3600. Usd/Jpy retested 110.00, with stops seen on a break of 110.05 and a major Fib around 110.20 after dovish BoJ vibes from the Summary of Opinions overnight that reiterated the need for ‘powerful’ monetary easing given the inflation remains a long way from the 2% target. However, the headline pair is drifting back down again towards 109.50 amidst a general Usd retracement.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and US Treasuries appear to be steering the latest broad upturn in fixed, while Gilts tread more cautiously as the clock ticks down to the BoE. Market contacts were looking the 159.03-06 area to be tested after 158.94 and 159.00, with a breach then exposing 159.18 vs the new 159.10 (+1/4 point) Eurex high so far, and more accurately flagged support bang on the current low where a chart gap lay. Similarly, near term support around Wednesday’s session base held in UST futures and the 10 year contract has also found dip buyers to revisit a rising trend-line that now forms a first line of resistance (119-13+ to 119-15). A break would bring 119-19 into the equation, then 119-24+ before the month to date peak at 119-31+.

COMMODITIES

Energy prices are currently coming off overnight highs in which crude prices extended on the advances as traders adjust to supply disruption concerns in the wake of the US withdrawal from the Iran nuclear agreement. Following this withdrawal, Israeli military have increased the number of strikes targeted at dozens of Iranian facilities in retaliation to an Iranian rocket attack on the occupied Golan Heights, signalling a continued escalation of geopolitical tensions in the region. Yesterday’s DOE printed a larger than expected drawdown, providing some support to the complex. WTI (+0.7%) and Brent (+0.6%) crude prices are firmly above the USD 71.00/bbl and USD 77.00/bbl respectively. UBS expects Brent to trade at USD 80/bbl in 6 months (prior forecast at USD 65/bbl) and WTI to trade at a USD 5/bbl discount to Brent (prior USD 4/bbl discount). Elsewhere, gold prices are trading flat amid a slight easing of the greenback, while London copper saw modest gains on the back of lower inventories.

Financials are up 0.1% aided by RBS’s (+4.1%) lower than  expected pay-out on MBS sales during the financial crisis, and UniCredit’s (+2.4%) positive financial results.

COMMODITIES

subject: UK debt and STIR futures: firmly braced for BoE and UK data prelude to super Thursday
content: The Short Sterling strip is nudging higher, tentatively, while Gilts are testing the water above 122.00 awaiting today’s big UK event and the latest BoE policy decision, QIR and press conference from Governor Carney.  The action starts at noon with the bar set very high for any change in rates, but the devil will be in the detail given that tightening expectations were running at 90%+ only a month or so ago. Hence, the vote split and tone of the minutes will be pivotal for markets seeking fresh guidance amidst ongoing doubt about Brexit and following a marked loss of economic momentum, which is only partly weather-related. Also on today’s super busy domestic slate, ip, manufacturing/construction output, trade and the NIESR GDP forecast for the quarter ending April (forecast at 0.3% q/q vs 0.2% previously and the paltry 0.1% preliminary print from the ONS for Q1). Back to Liffe, the core 10 year bond is currently at the base of 121.96-122.11 trading parameters vs Wednesday’s 121.90 close and 3 month futures are flat-2 ticks above parity.

Melrose Industries (MRO LN) – FY sales USD 150mln, board intends to review existing remuneration package and consult with shareholders in coming months. (Newswires)

TP ICAP (TCAP LN) – revenue in 4 months of GBP 601mln, 3% higher than prev. consistent with FY guidance in March. (Newswires)

Next (NXT LN) – Q1 total brand sales -4.1% vs. Exp. -6.1%. Co. says sales in online business were +18.1% and particularly strong. New upgraded central guidance for 2018 group profit before tax GBP 717mln vs. Prev. GBP 705mln. Co. anticipates EPS will be enhanced by 4.7% as a result of share buyback. (Newswires)

Randgold (RRS LN) – Quarterly group production lower at 286.89K ounce vs. Q4 production 340.958K ounce. Total dividend +100% to USD 2.00/shr. 2018 production guidance remained intact despite a softer Q1 in which it contended with multiple challenges. (Newswires)

BAE Systems (BA/ LN) – Group’s outlook remains unchanged with 2018 underlying EPS expected to be inline with 2017. (Newswires)

RSA Insurance (RSA LN) – Gross written premiums +1% against prior year. Net written premiums +2% to GBP 1.517bln on an underlying basis. Co. says weather losses elevated due to a tougher winter. (Newswires)

Coca-Cola HBC (CCH LN) – Quarterly net sales revenue EUR 1.35bln vs. prev. EUR 1.38bln, quarterly volumes +2.3%. (Newswires)

WM Morrison Supermarkets (MRW LN) – for 13 weeks up to 6th May, LfL sales excluding fuel +3.6%, including fuel +1.9%, total sales up 3.8% excluding fuel, +2.1% including it, expectations unchanged. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
10th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded positive across the board following the energy-fuelled upside on Wall St, where oil names outperformed as crude gained in the wake of Trump's withdrawal from the Iran nuclear agreement and DoEs. As such, ASX 200 (+0.3%) was led by the energy sector as oil edged fresh multi-year highs last seen in 2014 and with RBOB also at its best levels since mid-2015, while Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) was also marginally higher amid earnings and with Mitsubishi Motors shares outpacing the broader market after it beat on its FY net and guided sales higher. Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) and Hang Seng (+0.9%) shrugged off another liquidity drain by the PBoC to trade positive in which Hong Kong resumed its recent trend of outshining its regional peers, while participants also digested mixed Chinese inflation figures that showed CPI missed estimates at 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.9% although PPI growth gathered pace for the 1st time in 7-months to 3.4% as expected. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with demand lacking amid gains in riskier assets while a 10yr inflation-indexed auction was also largely ignored and failed to spur price action.

FTSE

UK Gambling Names – The UK government could delay their decision to impose stake reductions on UK betting machines, according to UK press reports. (Times)

RBS (RBS LN) – The co. agrees to a USD 4.9bln penalty in order to end the probe over the banks actions in the 2008 crash. (FT)

Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN) – COO Simon Kirby is stepping down after 19 months in the job. (FT)

Sky (SKY LN) – 21st Century Fox’s Chairman said they are to press ahead with the proposed merger with Disney and take hold of Sky, but said the company will consider offers if Comcast makes a higher bid. (Newswires)

EX-DIVS: Admiral Group (ADM LN), BP (BP LN), Centrica CNA.L, GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN), Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN), Sage Group (SGE LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 22.9 points off the FTSE 100

OTHER UK COMPANIES

DAX

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Aareal Bank (ARL GY) – Q1 operating profit of EUR 67mln vs. prev. EUR 71mln, FY outlook confirmed. (Newswires)

1&1 Drillisch (DRI GY) – Q1 revenues +44.9% to EUR 904.3mln. EBITDA +55.1% to EUR 165.5mln. Co. confirms 2018 forecast. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Axa (CS FP) – The IPO of Axa’s US branch has raised USD 2.75bln, USD 1bln less than what was expected, as investors showed concern over the prospect for life and pensions sectors. (FT)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

EDF (EDF FP) – Q1 sales up 1.9% from Q1 2017 to EUR 2.6bln. Nuclear output totalled 112.9twh, up 4.4twh from Q1 2017. Confirmed 2018 targets.(Newswires)

TechnipFMC (FTI FP) – Q1 revenue USD 3.1252bln vs. Prev. USD 3.388bln. Q1 adj. EPS USD 0.28 excluding items. Co. increases onshore/offshore guidance. Co. remains confident that subsea orders will grow in 2018. (Newswires)

Rubis (RUI FP) – Q1 Revenue EUR 1.22bln vs EUR 896mln y/y. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

Banco BPM (BAMI IM) - Q1 Revenue EUR 1.17bln vs Exp. EUR 1.14bln, Confirms sale EUR5bln in bad debt by June. (Newswires)

Poste Italiane (PST IM) – Q1 net profit +38% from Q1 2017 at EUR 485mln. Q1 revenue EUR 2.88bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.88bln Q1 EBIT EUR 703mln vs. Exp. EUR 595mln. (Newswires)

Unicredit (UCG IM) – Q1 net profit EUR 1.1bln vs. Exp. EUR 0.766bln. Q1 revenue EUR 5.1bln vs. Exp. EUR 4.96bln. Fully-phased CET1 capital ratio 13.06% (Dec-Mar) vs. Prev. 13.60% (end-Dec). Co. confirms ROTE above 9% in 2019. Separately, the co. is considering legal action to protect the bank following Caius’ letter on capital instruments..(Newswires)

Enel (ENEL IM) – Q1 group net ordinary profit +10% YY to EUR 1.041bln. Q1 ordinary EBITDA +3.9% YY to EUR 3.91bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.95bln. revenues -2.2% YY to EUR 18.95bln. Co. confirms financial targets for 2018. Co. board approves issue of one or more non-convertible subordinated hybrid bonds for up to EUR 3.5bln by end-2019. (Newswires)

Yoox Net-A-Porter (YNAP IM) – The online luxury retailer is set to be delisted after the ending of a takeover offer by Cartier owner Richemont, whom now own 94.99% of shares. (Newswires)

Tod’s (TOD IM) – The co. has said their LfL sales should visibly improve in Q2 and turn positive in the second half of the year. This figure was -4.4% YY. (Newswires)

SBM Offshore (SBMO NA) - Year to date revenue EUR 385mln, in line with expectations, directional net debt decreased by USD 550mln to USD 2.4bln at end of Q1, directional revenue and EBITDA guidance maintained. (Newswires)

DIA (DIA SM) – Q1 net sales EUR 1.88bln vs. prev. EUR 2.10bln, adj. EBITDA EUR 109.8mln vs. prev. EUR 123.0mln. (Newswires)

Repsol (REP SM) – Co. is in discussions to purchase assets from Viesgo for EUR 500mln, according to sources. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Marine Harvest (MHG NO) – Q1 revenue EUR 862mln vs. Exp. EUR 822mln. Quarterly dividend NOK 2.60 vs. Exp. NOK 2.43. Co. sees 2018 harvest of 400K tonnes vs. Prev. 410K tonnes. Co. sees 2018 global industry supply growth at 1%-6% vs. Prev. 3%-8%. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

COLOPLAST (COLOB DC) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT BERENBERG

SMI

BROKER MOVES

ROCHE (ROG SW) DOWNGRADED TO MARKET PERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM AT BERNSTEIN

US

US equity markets jumped higher, in line with energy prices, amid broad-based gains across most sectors. The energy sector outperformed on the back of higher oil prices, with Exxon (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) amongst outperformers in the DJI. As markets saw a risk on tone the defensive nature of utilities led to the sector being one of the largest underperformers among with the telecom sector.

Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with demand lacking amid gains in riskier assets while a 10yr inflation-indexed auction was also largely ignored and failed to spur price action.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day and CNY 10bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 20bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3768 (Prev. 6.3733)

Chinese CPI (Apr) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)
Chinese PPI (Apr) Y/Y 3.4% vs. Exp. 3.4% (Prev. 3.1%)

BoJ Summary of Opinions for April 26th-27th meeting stated it is appropriate to pursue powerful monetary easing under current guidelines as inflation is still a distant from the 2% target. Furthermore, the release noted that the rate of CPI Y/Y growth is likely to continue on its uptrend and increase toward 2%, while it added that BoJ is buying ETFs and risky assets as part of efforts to reach inflation goal but must look at potential merits and demerits of this action. (Newswires)

The Malaysian general election results showed a surprise victory for the opposition Pakatan Harapan coalition which won 121 out of the 222 parliamentary seats vs. only 79 seats for the incumbent Barisan Nasional headed by PM Najib Razak. However, PM Najib Razak commented that no party received a simple majority and that it is up to the King to select a new PM with the decision to be made on who will get the trust of the members of parliament, while PM-Elect Mahathir stressed the importance to have a government formed today and hopes to be sworn in as PM by 5pm local time today. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK RICS House Price Balance (Apr) -8% vs. Exp. -1% (Prev. 0%). (Newswires)

EU officials suggest that the EU is looking to find a way forward to maintain trade between the UK and EU post-Brexit despite having reservations about PM May’s current plans. (Newswires)

ECB's Lane (Dovish) said it is too soon to say if the demand slowdown is hurting the European economy. (Newswires)

Forza Italia's Berlusconi gave the go-ahead for a 5-Star/League government, although Berlusconi said his party will not give this coalition backing in parliament though and will remain allied to the League. (Newswires)

FX

NZD stole the spotlight overnight with the currency pressured after the RBNZ policy meeting in which it kept rates unchanged as expected and stated that it expects to maintain the OCR at the current expansionary level for a considerable time to maximize sustainable employment and stable inflation. Furthermore, the RBNZ noted that the next direction in rates is equally a hike or cut, while a couple of financial institutions pushed back their forecasts for a rate hike in response to the rhetoric. Elsewhere, the rest of the G10 currencies were relatively quiet with the DXY slightly easing back to the 93.00 level and with commodity-linked currencies remaining firm following the strength across the energy complex, while MYR non-deliverable forwards declined on uncertainty following the surprise opposition win at the general elections and with incumbent PM Najib Razak seemingly refusing to concede.

RBNZ Interest Rate Decision (May) 1.75% vs. Exp. 1.75% (Prev. 1.75%). (Newswires)
RBNZ said that it expects to maintain OCR at this expansionary level for a considerable time and that current level is best to maximize sustainable employment and stable inflation, while it also noted the next direction in rates is equally a hike or cut.
RBNZ said domestic economic growth is robust, while it cited subdued wages, low food & import price inflation for low inflation. RBNZ also maintained forecasts for where it sees OCR through to September 2019 in which it OCR estimates were kept at 1.8% for September 2018 and June 2019, while the estimate for September 2019 was maintained at 1.90%.

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded higher in which crude prices extended on the advances seen in the wake of the US withdrawal from the Iran nuclear agreement and following the larger than expected DOE crude inventory drawdown, with WTI and Brent crude prices firmly above the USD 71.00/bbl and USD 77.00/bbl respectively. Elsewhere, gold prices were marginally higher amid a mild a slight easing of the greenback, while copper also saw modest gains on the back of the positive risk tone.

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said Iran sanctions will come into effect 'very shortly' and that Iran "will negotiate" or "something will happen", while there were later comments from the White House that the US is preparing to add additional sanctions on Iran as soon as next week. (Newswires)

Israel Defense Forces conducted operations on Iran targets in Syria overnight. Newswires)

US

Treasury yields were higher across the curve with 5yr, 10yr and 30yr up by c.3bps. The 10yr yield hit session highs at 3.014% on Wednesday and held just above 3%, shrugging off soft PPI figures and after the 10yr auction tailed by 0.1bps. The yield came in at 2.995%, the highest since January 2014. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 8 ticks lower at 119-8+.

Fed’s Bostic (voter, dovish) said inflation is likely to run above 2% for a while and noted overshooting is not a problem. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia maintains energy-fuelled upside; NZD slipped after RBNZ signals rates are going nowhere for a considerable period, while MYR NDFs pressured on surprise election result and with PM Najib seemingly defiant
content:
Asia stocks traded positive across the board following the energy-fuelled upside on Wall St, where oil names outperformed as crude gained in the wake of Trump's withdrawal from the Iran nuclear agreement and following a larger than expected drawdown in DoE crude stockpiles. As such, ASX 200 (+0.3%) was led by the energy sector as oil edged fresh multi-year highs last seen in 2014 and with RBOB also at its best levels since mid-2015, while Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) was also marginally higher amid earnings and with Mitsubishi Motors shares outpacing the broader market after it beat on its FY net and guided sales higher.
